fields.headline: Press Gazette
fields.bodyText: Journalists and newspaper executives claim the new share-tipping laws "will brand journalists as criminals", according to News International's Les Hinton. BBC news chief Richard Sambrook is planning to launch a weekly current affairs show, which could involve resuscitating the magazine programme Here and Now. David Sullivan has named his forthcoming Sunday newspaper UK. It will be edited by Sunday Sport editor Tony Livesey. War has broken out between the Guardian's editor Alan Rusbridger and the Barclay Brothers' right-hand man Andrew Neil. The ITC has unveiled rules on the recording of telephone calls by journalists and programme makers. It will become essential to disclose the recording of a conversation unless "it is clear the material so acquired is essential to establish the credibility of a story". The Daily Mail and the Mail on Sunday have been accused of offering two online publications money after breaching their copyright. The National Magazine Company's science and technology magazine Focus could be extended into a masthead TV series with the Discovery Channel.
